author: dwdsquared2
body:
If anyone doesn't fully understand some of the basic concepts of options trading, I am linking some of Tastytrade's learning videos here.  Even if you have been trading them for years, you may not truly know.  Take time to review the basics and keep yourself aware of what any untapped potential you may be missing out on.  Good for a weekend review.

* **The Basics**
   * [Call Options](https://youtu.be/kmQ20J_3K7Q), [Put Options](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAwDrUqpGUI&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=3&t=0s)
   * [Option Premium](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qlsVYBRGkPM&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=6&t=0s), [Strike Price](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PM08yjp1WHQ&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=7&t=0s), [Breakeven Price](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ytHPhvVXDVY&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=28&t=0s)
   * [OTM (Out-of-the-Money) & ITM (In-the-Money)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zXBo-ebwAvo&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=8&t=0s)
   * Option Expiration
      * [Option Expiration: Part 1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x1c6CsO5nyk&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=9&t=0s), [Option Expiration: Part 2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PIOnNoXgtCI&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=10&t=0s)
      * [Holding an Option Through Expiration](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqIgnMGzSTU&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=11&t=0s)
   * [Volume & OI (Open Interest)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7K3navPkzlU&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=22&t=0s), [The (Bid-Ask) Spread](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y_RtP2Wjeo4&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=23&t=0s)
   * [Rolling a Trade](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VqsFQNOocB4&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=54&t=0s)
* **Volatility (IV)**
   * [Historic vs. Implied](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=amao0pJE1XI&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=30&t=0s)
   * [How Option Prices Drive IV](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ktNd2twSaQ&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=31&t=0s), [Why IV Increases When Prices Drop](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dta56P24RPM&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=35&t=0s)
* **The Greeks**
   * [Delta](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1B3uvJBD4g&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=40&t=0s), [Gamma](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2ty3MuQ68Q&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=42&t=0s), [Vega](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jN7gCO0PWc&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=45&t=0s)
   * [Theta](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCtTVaRxTNE&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=43&t=0s)
      * [Trading With Theta In Mind](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XKJLkULz9bA&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=44&t=0s)
* **The Different Types of Spreads**
   * Common
      * [Debit - Vertical](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ptxT5wdWfJQ&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=69&t=0s)
      * [Credit - Vertical Put](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7QfablpqeQc&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=86&t=0s)
      * [Calendar](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BgP72h9V52I&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=101&t=0s)
      * [Straddle - Short](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qg-VEjB9NAQ&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=84&t=0s), [Strangle - Short](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNv1UYRawB8&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=81&t=0s)
      * [Wider Option Spreads](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TvLjGprWaEQ&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=117&t=0s)
   * Advanced
      * [Butterfly - Broken Wing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sjCWOmn4OgA&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=95&t=0s)
      * [Big Lizard](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8tOrXpsWGg0&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=106&t=0s), [Jade Lizard](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKkz2AM5rRA&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=103&t=0s)
      * [Iron Condor](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k7Q9BSaF7cY&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=87&t=0s), [Iron Fly](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MqB7BGBLXYw&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=94&t=0s)
      * [Ratio](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Aok7J4Gj6w&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=109&t=0s)
* **Basic Trading Guides**
   * [3 Keys to Trading Options in a Small Account](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IQ4LcLHU1sA&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=61&t=0s)
   * [3 Strategies for New Traders](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B8Er4CsSZKI&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=62&t=0s)
   * [3 Credit Strategies for Earnings](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VEWQAmjGIo8&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=63&t=0s)
   * [Dividend Risk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTWTW4S8u-M&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=119&t=0s)
   * [Hedging Positions](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1iYQ0XOLHNU&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=114&t=0s)
   * [3 Considerations for Losing Trades](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=36nfafOjkTw&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=111&t=0s)
   * [Deciding to Close a Options Trade](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fg9WDm0jHvA&list=PLPVve34yolHY43YaBegHMzN9WjrTnQfFr&index=112&t=0s)
   * [Selling Put Options in Smaller Portfolios](https://youtu.be/7XgXvyg9mOQ)
* [Playlist: Options Trading with a $2,500 Portfolio](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T1eMaBlHHlI&list=PLPVve34yolHaZAlzcbPIZsf-RAX4m_b6w)

author: Milazzo
body:
Here is the thing - I worked in the industry that needed that data. 

It isn't personal mostly, it is demographic. And Google still thinks I am a 55+ man. (I am not). Big brother can collect all the data in the world, but the holy grail not solved yet is individual sense of that data. If that makes anyone feel better. 

Columnar databases can only have so many index keys. You are more likely just a group of demographics for marketing reasons.

author: manic_schoolbus
body: Every bitcoin 'wallet' has a public and private key.  The public key is a string of letters and numbers you use in sending BTC units to the wallet, the one that's OK to share in public like an email address (though anyone can look up that address and see how much BTC is in it).  The private key is composed of the 'seed words' and should be hidden, as it grants access to the BTC in the wallet.  From what I understand, the more seed words involved makes the encryption harder to crack.  And people come up with creative ways to hide the private keys, like engraving or splitting up the list, or even memorizing it.

author: titanium_hydra
body:
"The art of losing isn’t hard to master;  
so many things seem filled with the intent  
to be lost that their loss is no disaster.

Lose something every day. Accept the fluster  
of lost door keys, the hour badly spent.  
The art of losing isn’t hard to master.

Then practice losing farther, losing faster:  
places, and names, and where it was you meant  
to travel. None of these will bring disaster.

I lost my mother’s watch. And look! my last, or  
next-to-last, of three loved houses went.  
The art of losing isn’t hard to master.

I lost two cities, lovely ones. And, vaster,  
some realms I owned, two rivers, a continent.  
I miss them, but it wasn’t a disaster.

—Even losing you (the joking voice, a gesture  
I love) I shan’t have lied. It’s evident  
the art of losing’s not too hard to master  
though it may look like (*Write* it!) like disaster."

One Art

By Elizabeth Bishop

author: capitalistsanta
body: This is weird advice and don’t take this as “dont invest”: invest SO much man, but invest in the new stuff. Stocks are the rich mans game in 2020, this isn’t 1950 anymore, stocks are the price that they are at because of a lot of manipulation by our government. I like that you’re in small caps. Learn about Cryptocurrency: Bitcoin, Ethereum, Ampleforth, Decentralized Finance, staking, private keys, exchanges, absorb it all. Jump into the new stuff don’t even think about it just learn as you go. IMO there’s more opportunity in Cryptocurrency than Stocks and I personally think it’s more fun and a 24 hour market and can be done entirely on your phone if you want and buying in is so cheap right now, like pennies to invest in good tokens. If you don’t believe me check out AERGO, a Token that has more impressive partnerships than hundreds of thousands of companies in the stock market. I don’t think that dropping money into an index fund is a BAD idea, but IMO it’s more of an 80s-2010s idea that isn’t going to be as successful when the market is so disconnected from the realities facing America at the moment. I would HIGHLY recommend “How to Make Money in Stocks” by William ONeil; the founder of Investor Business Daily. His strategies helped me make money in crypto this month in particular. But man just learn. That shit is free. Learn, explore, make folders and book mark shit. Definitely also recommend “Steal Like an Artist”

author: Pizza_Bagel_
body:
This will inevitably get downvoted but I don't care. My dad and I run a little family hedge fund of sorts. I can't make as much as him because I simply don't have the same amount, but I'm up 13% this year and it's my first year investing. (I had shit mutual funds until I woke up this year, after realizing that the work I was doing with my dad could be done with my own money too.)

My dad, however, has turned $170,000 into nearly half a million since this past September, using short options strategies. The idiots on WSB can't accept the truth of the matter, but it's the people selling options that are making all the money. Along with my help, he's developed a strategy of shorting options right ATM, usually covered calls and usually on earnings. HE collects fat premiums, and either gets assigned or doesn't. If not assigned, he just keeps selling calls and might even run the price up a bit for a swing trade esque profit.

That's in addition to his long accounts that he doesn't touch, in which he's up over 10x since 2010. u/SugarAdamAli has a pretty good list, but I'd add AMD, Facebook, NVDA, and V. AMD especially is going to the moon. Lisa Su is a straight up generational genius and is poised to start eating market share that's incredibly valuable and highly up for grabs. Overall, I think Amazon is the best stock in the world right now though.

What I don't agree with u/SugarAdamAli on is that the key is the price. Wrong. There are many keys, and the price is just one of them. If it was all about the price then any company with a high P/E and at an ATH wouldn't be worth buying. AMD has both, and I think is still undervalued. (AMD will be at 500 before 2030, and I think that's conservative.) If there's any 'key,' it's buying good companies and doing it with concentrated amounts.

Also, diversification is a term that's been beaten to death and people don't understand it anymore. You don't get rich by buying 500 companies which includes Macy's for Christ's sakes. Depending on how much money you have, you buy 10-20 all star companies and keep tabs on their progress.

The options strategy is another ballgame. There are many ways of approaching it. The best way to sum it up in a few words (even though I could write a book on it, because most people clearly don't understand how and when to use it) is that you never write on companies you wouldn't mind owning. That's a lot different than going straight up long, since going long you only want the companies you have conviction in, the ones you think are going to the moon. With options, I'd write, say, a short ATM put against SBUX, because they're a great company with a solid stock and on an earnings week the premiums will be solid. Oh, and also, you write weeklies. People writing anything longer dated can't do math, and apparently that's most people.

author: Hollowpoint38
body:
>I dunno man, more features = more things that break.

I don't think it's a linear curve like that.  That would mean cars are becoming less reliable every year and that's not the case.  The last time I had to take a car in for a mechanical failure was 10 years ago.  20 years ago things would happen all the time.  It's down now where QC is pretty good.  Oil changes are every 10,000 miles now and not every 3,000 miles.

>Buy a Honda from 20 years ago with no features. Tough plastic that doesnt move or do anything breaks. Let alone sensors, cameras, turbos, electrical shit, gaskets, bearings. And Mercedes parts are not cheap.

You should be leasing these cars, not buying and holding on to them for 20 years.  If your car is less than 3 years old, you're not going to have camera and sensor problems.  Then after 3 years you cut a small check and you get the keys to a new one.

Here's to a better next week!

author: sharknado523
body:
Because for everything that resulted in a 1,000% gain there are so many that result in losses. No one had any idea $TSLA was going to octuple in like three years. It was absurd to think it at the time, and it's absurd now. Sustainable, repeatable, consistent gains are the only way to become wealthy.

The thing about the Bitcoin hard drive sucks. That is a huge problem with cryptocurrency. I read somewhere that 1/5 of all BTC is completely unusable due to lost keys and hard drives. Nevertheless I recognize that feeling of loss.

The important thing is you learn from "mistakes" and you can't let FOHMO (fear of having missed out) cause you take on undue risk in future trades. There was some guy on r/wallstreetbets that got his account from $10,000 to $700,000 and then lost it all.

You'll get there - it's hard to feel that way. It happens to all of us. "I was looking at that stock, I should've bought it instead of what I bought" or "I should've put some money into $TSLA calls, it was going up, everyone said it was going to the moon." But you can't kick yourself over that stuff. Because remember, for every buyer there is a seller. And the guy who paid $2,000+ for $TSLA today because he had the same dollar signs in his eyes, he's got a shot of that stock going either way. Only time will tell how sustainable this rally is and just how much of these new gains the stock is going to be able to consolidate.

author: AnInterestedFellow
body: I once worked in a cash vault for a very large bank.  The vault was probably the oldest part of the building and had these storage “lockers” which we didn’t have the keys for.  One day we received notice that some guy had wanted to reclaim a 672 oz stash of silver held in one of the lockers.  He provided paperwork from the early 80’s and once we confirmed ownership, we called in a locksmith to drill the lock.  It was a huge “loaf” of silver, all one piece and very rough from the smelting process.  It had tarnish all over it from sitting in a vault for 30 or so years and had the weight stamped in it.  I was expecting smooth, perfectly shaped bars like you see in the movies, but it was nothing like that.  None the less though, very very cool.

author: bmathew5
body:
I started investing in December of 2019 and just as things were looking good, Corona crashed it all in march. I was down about 35% and I was so nervous because I was still learning and I thought I made a grave mistake. Roughed through it, started researching more on strategies, listening to the gurus, looking for companies that fit my risk tolerance and now up 35%. 

I had no idea how RRSPs and TFSAs worked. I just spent a solid month learnings the ins and outs and how to really leverage it to my advantage. Hell, I even have a financial advisor set up my RRSP when I was 20 and it's made peanuts compared to what I've managed on my own. I'm going to try and move those TD Index Funds into my own RRSP portfolio and do it my way. 

I used to think getting rich was by working really hard and getting a high paying job. That helps but compound interest and money management are the real keys. That's why the rich get richer. I finally hit my goal of a 6-figure portfolio a month ago and I my goal was the end of the year. Let's see what the next 12 months bring!

author: DividendWin
body:
Decentralization is the state of having as little of an oversight as possible. The core of the fiscal centralization in this case is very low but the algorithm itself is a form of centralization; to produce a bitcoin however you do need some kind of centralizing algorithm otherwise mining wouldn't work, you couldn't buy or sell anything with it, and it would effectively be an infinite resource. 

Basically it works like this: In order to play any game with another person you need some form of central rule. Yes, the rules can be extremely tight (Chess) or extremely lax (Your common MMO build variety including horrible ideas and combinations), but the rules must be there. Bitcoin is as decentralized as it likely can get, albeit if you further the onlook, a mining farm, BTC exchanges, etc. are all forms of centralization. 

The decentralization however does indeed force it into a fiat state. It's an ironic bid; if you and I agree that a BTC is worth *N* then that's one thing but if you and I can exchange it, publicly, with a great portion of the world agreeing that BTC is worth *N* then it has to have some form of intermediary to work that out and generate a consensus. The intrinsic value of a BTC would be, theoretically, whatever electricity it required, in a purely decentralized state without farms, exchanges, or other production and distribution elements. 

>BTC is a scarce, fixed supply asset. Only 21M will ever come into existence; this will not/cannot change. Supply cannot be inflated; it’s a non correlated, deflationary store of value.

So this is not correct. The fact that it is scare (artificially) should not be mistaken for it being *valuable*. First, let's look at some facts:

1. We've decided, arbitrarily, that BTC is a currency. This doesn't make any core sense relative to *actual scarcity*. If I told you that I made a really cool program that spat out random coins (i.e. other cryptocurrencies, ICOs, etc.) and to get to the coin all you had to do was play a little game (solve puzzle x) would you accept this as a currency? Because, it turns out, most artifacts at Antique Roadshow are exactly the same; they are indeed completely able to be reproduced (you can make other coins instead of bitcoin, there's no intrinsic reason why BTC is the standard, and so we have) but we present a value on the original for arbitrary reasons. This is important. The fact that a teacup set from 1700 is worth anything more than a teacup set from Target today is *completely arbitrary*.

2. BTC can be lost. That's one of the major problems with it; if you lose the private key the cash goes bye-bye *but the price doesn't reflect the lost keys* and so the scarcity is based entirely on what's been produced *not* what actually is in circulation. This is another reason why it doesn't make sense and is completely fiat; if I made the same coins and offered you the game above but then you lost some of it and couldn't get it back does that impact the value of the rest? Or rather, how would it? This immunity is not a good thing; supply actually can be inflated and deflated by just counting the pennies that aren't in play anymore due to either being stolen or lost. In practiced expectation eventually all of BTC will be lost; if you lost even .001% of the private keys a year this is an eventuality which drives down supply and up demand by inflation so if you purposefully dumped keys (much like how diamonds trade today) you could manipulate the price.

Now my point isn't to argue with you, per se, I am not that vested in the idea but more to express that it isn't this clear-cut superhero method of practice. Any type of communal value requires some form of centralization to form and so, de facto, BTC isn't completely decentralized and likely won't stay decentralized and just p2p because if that's the case the exchanges have to disband and farms have to disappear.

author: johntmssf
body:
Or, people could take responsibility for themselves. It's an age restricted app. They add check boxes on the options enabling to say "before we give you the keys, do you know how to drive?"

What makes Robinhood great is it allows me to discover on my own, gives me something to question that I then research and find a way. I don't want some kids app that's says "oh ah uh - that iron condor is too risky for you! Why don't you hold some $F stocks instead". Instead Robinhood gives you all the technical information, and you learn through experience what your own risk tolerance is.

Gambling addiction is real, some people learn the hard way about risk tolerance. Some people just don't know what they're doing. But just because some people can't handle it dosent mean it should be taken away from the people that can. 

That suicidal adult, while I deeply empathize with him and his family, was making his own final solution to something he didn't even bother googling or understanding. 

Robinhood is a tool, not a school, not an parent. Don't blame the hammer for hitting yourself on the thumb.

author: charnzilla
body: I just started doing this myself with BAC. Monthly OTM calls for about $40 premium. It’s not a lot but I’m using the revenue to buy shares of an etf that pays monthly dividends. I’m not actively managing them after I sell them because the commission would eat my profits. I’m also ok with the option being exercised. I’d still take a net profit from the whole thing and just buy back in if I wanted to. When I was doing background research one of the keys is to have confidence in the underlying this is why I went with BAC and lower premiums rather than DKNG (someone on another thread told me I should go DKNG). I don’t mind being long on BAC whereas I don’t have a good read on DKNG yet.
